newsitem.title: INDIA: India train blast latest outbreak of violence.
newsitem.headline: India train blast latest outbreak of violence.

text.p: A bomb blast that ripped through a passenger train in the northern Indian state of Punjab on Tuesday, killing at least 33 people, was the latest violent incident to strike the world's second most populous nation.
Following is a chronology of insurgency-related violence in India over the past 12 years:
June 1984 - Indian army storms Golden Temple in Amritsar, the Sikhs' holiest shrine, to flush out armed Sikh militants, killing about 1,000 people.
October 31, 1984 - Prime Minister Indira Gandhi assassinated at her residence in New Delhi by two Sikh security bodyguards.
November 1984 - Nearly 3,000 people hacked or burnt to death, mostly in Delhi, during anti-Sikh riots.
May 1985 - Sikh extremists set off bombs in and around Delhi, killing 86 people.
June 1985 - An Air-India aircraft explodes and crashes into sea off the coast of Ireland, killing 329 people. Sikh extremists claim responsibility.
July 1987 - Sikh gunmen kill 70 Hindus in Delhi.
June 1989 - Sikh militants gun down 24 fundamentalist Hindus exercising in Punjab park.
November 1989 - Sikh militants kill 21 students outside college near Amritsar.
January 1990 - Indian army fires on demonstrators protesting in Srinagar against a crackdown on long-simmering independence movement, killing 38 and fuelling separatist campaign.
April 1990 - Militants bomb Hindu procession in Punjab, killing 32.
May 1990 - Moulvi Mohammed Farooq, chief Moslem priest of Kashmir, shot by unidentified gunmen. At least 50 people killed when troops fire on mourners bearing his body through Srinagar.
June 1990 - About 30 people killed in violence on sixth anniversary of Indian army assault on Golden Temple.
May 1991 - Some 68 Kashmiri guerrillas killed in shootout with army. Strike called by rebels in Kashmir, 14 killed.
May 21, 1991 - Former Indian prime minister Rajiv Gandhi, who sent troops to Sri Lanka in 1987, assassinated by Tamil suicide bomber in southern India during election campaign.
October 1991 - Two bombs explode in Rudrapur Nainital district of Uttar Pradesh, killing 55 people and injuring more than 100. Punjab militants suspected.
December 1992 - Hindu zealots tear down a 16th-century mosque in the northern city of Ayodhya. Incident triggers sectarian riots across India in which over 3,000 people die.
January 1993 - Militants kill 33 troops in Kashmir. Security forces torch scores of buildings and kill 53 people in retaliation.
March 12, 1993 - Thirteen bombs, thought to be planted by Moslem underworld figures, explode in quick succession around Bombay, killing 263.
August 31, 1995 - Punjab Chief Minister Beant Singh killed with 12 others in car bomb in Chandigarh.
January 3, 1996 - Seven people killed and 35 injured in explosion in teeming market street in New Delhi.
April 27, 1996 - Twelve people killed, 20 injured in bomb blast aboard bus in Modinagar outside Delhi.
May 22, 1996 - Powerful car bomb kills at least 12 people, injures 52 in busy market in South Delhi. Kashmir separatists claim responsibility
Nov 15, 1996 - Left-wing extremists kill 13 policemen and one civilian in a rocket attack on Sirpuru village in southern Andhra Pradesh state.

Dec 3, 1996 - Twelve passengers killed and 37 injured in the explosion in a sleeper coach at Ambala cantonment station near Chandigarh, capital of the northern state of Punjab. No one claims responsibility.
Dec 30, 1996 - Bomb rips through packed train in northeast Indian state of Assam, killing at least 48 people. Police blame Bodo separatist militants.
July 8, 1997 - Bomb rips through passsenger train in north India killing at least 33 and injuring 62.
